questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of dispersion?
questions.solution:
Z scores are not a measure of dispersion, they are measures of position. It indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution. 

The most common measures of spread/dispersion are range, standard deviation and variance. They help in determining the extent to which data is stretched/scattered or squeezed/clustered.

They are also called measures of spread or scatter or variability.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: What is standard deviation a measure of?
questions.solution:
Standard deviation is a measure of spread or dispersion or variability.

Range and variability are other measures of spread.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct relationship between variance and standard deviation?

choices.text: Variance = square root of standard deviation
Standard deviation = square root of variance

questions.solution:
Standard deviation is the square root of variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on chronic kidney disease in a population. Your sample size is 28. What formula for standard deviation will you use here?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the sample size is 28, which is <30. For a small sample, usually less than 30, the formula for standard deviation used is:

It is better to use n-1 in the denominator in the case of a small sample. But in the case of a very large sample subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. In those cases, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about standard deviation?

choices.text: One standard deviation covers 95% of the values
It can be used only in normal distributions
It is a measure of central tendency

questions.solution:
The standard deviation (S.D) indicates the distribution of variables. It is a measure of dispersion.

It can be used in normal and skewed distributions, but it is particularly useful in normal distributions.

1 S.D covers 68% of the values. 2 S.D covers 95% of the values.

Measures of central tendency are mean, median and mode.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

questions.text: You are using the Kuppuswamy scale to calculate the socio-economic status of 10 families in the railway staff quarters. You find that every family has a total monthly income of Rs. 73,355. What is the standard deviation of this sample?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the standard deviation will be zero.

The monthly income of every family is Rs. 73,355. So, all the elements in this distribution are the same. Hence, there is no variability. Both the standard deviation and variance which is the square of standard deviation will be zero.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

questions.text: Each value of a study sample is multiplied by 10. What would be the new standard deviation of the observations?
questions.solution:
When each element of a sample is multiplied by 10, the new standard deviation= 10 x original standard deviation.

The formula for standard deviation, SD = √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1.

If each element of the distribution is multiplied by 10, the new mean will become 10 times the original mean.

If all observations are multiplied by 10, then the new SD = √∑(10x-10x̄)2/n-1

= 10 √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1

= 10 x Original SD

Change in variance: variance = square of standard deviation, so when SD becomes 10 times, 

the variance will be  10² = 100 times the original variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

questions.text:
On plotting the blood pressure values of a population on a graph, you obtain the curve given below. Which of the following is true?
  1. It is a Gaussian distribution
  2. Mean = median ≠ mode
  3. It is defined by the mean and standard deviation
  4. There is no skew in the distribution
  5. The area under the curve depends on the mean
questions.solution:
The given image shows a normal distribution, also called bell curve or Gaussian distribution. It has no skew. It is defined by the mean and standard deviation. In a normal distribution, mean = median = mode.

The total area under the curve of a normal distribution is 1. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the standard normal distribution?
  1. It has a mean of 1.0
  2. It is bell shaped
  3. It has a standard deviation of 0.0
  4. It has a variance of 1.0
  5. Standard deviation = variance
questions.solution:
A standard normal distribution is a type of normal distribution. It is bell-shaped, has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. Thus the variance, the square of standard deviation is also 1 = the standard deviation.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of distribution of one standard deviation?
questions.solution:
Approximately 68% of a normal distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean. This is as per the empirical rule of a normal distribution.

Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.

Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

questions.text: During a study on anaemia in a population, a normal distribution curve with a mean of 13.5 g% is obtained. What proportion of the population constitutes people with haemoglobin values above 13.5 g%?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, 0.50, i.e., 50% of the population would have haemoglobin more than the mean, i.e., 13.5 gm%. In a normal distribution, 50% of the values lie above the mean.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

questions.text: The IQ scores of your study population form a bell-shaped curve. How much of the population falls between the median (Mdn) and Mdn + 1 S.D?
questions.solution:
34% or 0.34 of the population in a normal distribution falls between the median and median plus one standard deviation.

The IQ values form a bell-shaped curve, which is seen in normal symmetric distributions.

According to the empirical rule of normal distributions, 68% of the distribution falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean, i.e., mean ± 1 SD covers 68% of the distribution.

Now, in a normal distribution, mean = median. Therefore, this 68% includes values from median -1SD to median +1SD.

The question asks about the percentage that falls under median +1SD, which would be half of 68%, that is 34% or 0.34.

Below is the graphical representation of the question. The question is asking to calculate the shaded region in the graph.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text:
The fasting blood glucose levels of adults in a population forms a normal distribution. The statistical measures obtained are given below. Within what limits would 95% of the population have their blood glucose values?

Mean- 105 mg per 100 ml

Standard deviation- 10mg per 100 ml
questions.solution:
In this scenario, 95% of the population would have their blood sugar within the limits of 85 and 125 mg. Here, the mean blood sugar is 105 mg and the standard deviation is 10 mg.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean. 

In this question, 2 S.D = 10 x 2 = 20. We do, + and - 2 S.D from the mean to arrive at the limits within which 95% of the population would have their blood sugar, i.e., 85 and 125 mg.

+ and - 1 S.D = 10 from the mean, we get the limits within which 68% of the population would have their blood sugar value, i.e., 95 and 115 mg.

+ and - 3 S.D = 30, from the mean, we get limits within which 99% would have their values, i.e., 75 and 135 mg.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

questions.text:
While conducting a study on malnutrition, you record the following data. If it forms a normal distribution curve, which of the following is true for this sample?

No. of children: 100

Mean weight: 15kg

Standard deviation: 1.5kg

choices.text: Weight of 95 children is between 12 and 18 kg
Weight of 95 children is between 10.5 and 19.5 kg
Weight of 99 children is between 10 and 19 kg
Weight of 34 children is between 13.5 and 16.5 kg

questions.solution:
In this scenario, the weight of 95 children will be between 12 and 18 kg as the mean is 15 kg and the standard deviation is 1.5 kg.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean. Two standard deviations = 2 x 1.5 = 3 kg

The weight of 99.7% of children will be between 10.5-19.5 Kg, i.e., within three standard deviations.

The weight of 68% of children will be between 13.5 to 16.5 Kg, i.e., within one standard deviation. Half will weigh between 13.5 and 15kg and the other half between 15 and 16.5kg

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: The distribution of intraocular pressure (IOP) in 100 glaucoma patients form a normal distribution curve. It has a mean of 30 mm of Hg with a standard deviation (SD) of 1 mm of Hg. 97.5% of patients would have an IOP more than what value?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, 97.5% of patients would have an IOP of more than 28 mm of Hg.

The mean IOP is 30mm of Hg and SD is 1.0 mm of Hg. According to the empirical rule of the normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2 SD. So 95% of patients will have their IOP between 30 ± 2 = 28 to 32 mm of Hg. 

Out of the remaining 5%, half will have IOP < 28 and the other half will have > 32. So half of 5%= 2.5% has IOP <28mm Hg. Thus the remaining 97.5% has IOP > 28mm of Hg.

This is shown in the image given below

questions.text: A study is being conducted on anaemia in pregnancy. A normal distribution curve with a mean haemoglobin level of 10.6 gm/dL with a standard deviation of 2 gm/dL is obtained. Below what level would 5% of the women in the group have their haemoglobin values?
questions.solution:
5% of the pregnant women in this group will have their haemoglobin levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Solution:
Given Data :

  • Mean: 10.6 g/dL
  • Standard deviation : 2 g/dL

Step 1:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 95% of the population fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2SD. 
This implies that the remaining 5% lie outside 2 SD, i.e. 2.5% below 2 SD and 2.5% above 2 SD. 
Therefore , Mean - 2SD = 10.6 − 2 (2) 
                                    = 10.6 − 4 
                                    = 6.6 g/dL 
Thus, 2.5% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 6.6 g/dL.

However, the question asks about 5% and not 2.5%. So options C and D have been ruled out.

Now Let's move to the next step.

Step 2:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 68% of the population fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean, i.e., mean±1SD. 
This implies that the remaining 32% lie outside 1 SD, i.e., 16% below 1 SD and 16% above 1 SD. 
The value of mean−1 SD is 8.6 g/dL (i.e. 10.6 − 2) 
Thus, 16% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 8.6 g/dL.

so now option A is ruled out 

Step 3:

The value for 5% must lie between the values where 2.5% and 16% of the population lie, i.e., between 6.6g/dL and 8g/dL. Only option B, 7.31 g/dL, satisfies this condition.

Hence, 5% of pregnant women have their Hb levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: The peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) values of a group of 11-year-old girls have a mean of 300 l/min and a standard deviation of 20 l/min. What are the deviation scores for the PEFR values of two girls recorded as 280 l/min and 330 l/min respectively?
questions.solution:
The deviation scores for PEFR values 280 l/min and 330 l/min are -20 and 30 respectively.

The Deviation score of an element in a distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., it is obtained by subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.

Applying this here, deviation score of the value 280 l/min = the element - the mean = 280 - 300 = -20. 

For the value 330 l/min, deviation score = 330 - 300 = 30.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

questions.text: The shape of a normal distribution curve depends on?
questions.solution:
The shape of a normal distribution curve depends upon its mean and standard deviation.

For example, for a particular mean value, a smaller standard deviation value gives a taller and narrower curve whereas, a larger value gives a flatter curve. 

The curve is centered at the mean μ which coincides with the median and the mode and is located at the point beneath the peak of the curve. The mean, median and mode are equal.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of a normal distribution curve?
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution curve, mean = median.

mean > median in positively/ rightward skewed distribution.

mean < median in negatively/ leftward skewed distribution.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the standard normal distribution?
questions.solution:
In a standard normal distribution, mean = 0.

questions.text: A population study showed a mean glucose of 86 mg/dL. In a sample of 100 showing normal distribution, what percentage of people will have blood glucose above 86 mg/dL?
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution, 50% of the values lie above the mean.

In this scenario, 50% of the people will have a blood glucose level of more than 86 mg/dL.

questions.text: The mean value of marks in a distribution of 100 students in a class is 105 and standard deviation is 10. How many students will have their marks between 85 and 125?
questions.solution:
According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2 SD.

In this scenario, the marks between 85 and 125 fall within 2 standard deviation of the mean which is 105. Thus 95% of the students will have the marks in this range.

questions.text: The systolic blood pressure of a group of normal people between the ages of 25–27 years was taken and a mean of 120 mmHg was found. What will be the expected number of individuals among a group of 100 people taken for the study whose BP will be below 120 mmHg?
questions.solution:
In a normal distribution, 50% of the values lie below the mean.

In this scenario, 50%, i.e., 50 of the 100 people will have a systolic BP of less than 120 mmHg.

questions.text: In a normal distribution, what percentage of the distribution falls within 2 standard deviations of the mean?
questions.solution:
According to the empirical rule of normal distributions, 95% of the distribution falls within 2 standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2 SD covers 95% of the distribution.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the mean +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Mean +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Mean+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Mean+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260
